title: Get Started
text: package extension, new admiral best place first start reading Get Started page. extension package follows main idea conventions, re-uses many functions admiral, important thoroughly understand able use admiralpeds.

title: Get Started
text: can see guidance create select ADaMs pediatric clinical trials reading vignettes User Guides section site. admiralpeds also provides template R scripts starting point. can created calling use_ad_template() admiral, e.g., list available templates can obtained list_all_templates() admiral:
code: library(admiral) use_ad_template(   adam_name = "advs",   save_path = "./ad_advs.R",   package = "admiralpeds" ) list_all_templates(package = "admiralpeds") #> Existing ADaM templates in package 'admiralpeds': #> • ADVS

title: Creating a Pediatrics ADVS ADaM
text: article describes creating vital signs ADaM pediatric clinical trials. main focus around Anthropometric indicators (.e. growth development chart) parameter derivations Height, Weight, Body Mass Index (BMI), Head Circumference. advise first consult admiral Creating BDS Finding ADaM vignette. programming workflow around create general set-ADVS using admiral functions , save repeating information maintaining content two places instead opted focus pediatric-specific steps . Note: examples assume CDISC SDTM /ADaM format input unless otherwise specified.

title: Creating a Pediatrics ADVS ADaM
text: Metadata Initial ADVS Set-Derive Additional Variables Anthropometric indicators Derive Additional Parameters Anthropometric indicators Remaining ADVS Set-

previous_headings: Programming Workflow
title: Creating a Pediatrics ADVS ADaM
text: required packages loaded, first step prepare metadata. made default decisions package metadata use free replace source prefer (long keep structure dataframe consistent - expected downstream functions). example, might want use different age range selection metadata (including reference data ages 5-19 years) even alternatively International Obesity Task Force standards. selection standard reference files included used metadata package follows: 2000 CDC Growth Charts BMI : 2022 CDC Extended BMI--age Growth Charts 2006 Growth Standards - Expanded Tables: Birth 5 years
code: library(admiral) library(admiralpeds) library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) library(lubridate) library(stringr)

previous_headings: Programming Workflow > Metadata
what: Reference Files for Parameters by Age
title: Creating a Pediatrics ADVS ADaM
text: growth rates patterns differ sex, different reference values used accordingly different age groups. applicable parameters (height/weight/BMI), made default decision rely standards children <2 years age (<730.5 days) CDC standards children >=2 years age (>=730.5 days). made accordance CDC recommendation. , first step needed combine various metadata parameter ensuring sex age shown consistent way. Additionally, CDC growth charts offer monthly intervals took advice ex-CDC expert area made decision template add interpolation code record day age. converting CDC months days use rounding bring whole number days. prefer rely solely monthly chart , remove rounding call derive_interp_records() function. pre-processing metadata using following code BMI example: combined metadata BMI now looks age ranges around 2 years show CDC standards combined: help interpret metadata: LMS parameters median (M), generalized coefficient variation (S), power Box-Cox transformation (L). Sigma dispersion parameter used calculation BMI percentiles z-scores 95th percentile, P95 represents sex age-specific 95th percentile. example shows parameter BMI, similar follows parameters like weight height (except Sigma P95 ). Note however head circumference parameter metadata comes standards, equivalent >2 years age provided CDC.
code: # Default reference sources: WHO for children <2 yrs old (< 730.5 days), # and CDC for children >=2 yrs old (>= 730.5 days) data(WHO_bmi_for_age_boys) data(WHO_bmi_for_age_girls) data(cdc_bmiage)  bmi_for_age <- who_bmi_for_age_boys %>%   filter(Day < 730.5) %>%   mutate(SEX = "M") %>%   bind_rows(who_bmi_for_age_girls %>%     filter(Day < 730.5) %>%     mutate(SEX = "F")) %>%   rename(AGE = Day) %>%   bind_rows(cdc_bmiage %>%     mutate(       SEX = case_when(         SEX == 1 ~ "M",         SEX == 2 ~ "F",         TRUE ~ NA_character_       ),       # Ensure first that Age unit is "DAYS"       AGE = round(AGE * 30.4375)     ) %>%     # Interpolate the AGE by SEX     derive_interp_records(       by_vars = exprs(SEX),       parameter = "BMI"     ) %>%     # Keep patients >= 2 yrs till 20 yrs - Remove duplicates for 730 Days old which     # must come from WHO metadata only     filter(AGE >= 730.5 & AGE <= 7305)) %>%   # AGEU is added in metadata, required for derive_params_growth_age()   mutate(AGEU = "DAYS") %>%   arrange(AGE, SEX)

previous_headings: Programming Workflow > Metadata
what: Reference Files for Weight by Length/Height
title: Creating a Pediatrics ADVS ADaM
text: provides additional standards weight body length (recumbent length), instead age. combined metadata sex single reference file. also weight height files available, upon advice ex-CDC expert area chose include body length files, children able stand BMI age appropriate measure use. However, template give metadata values variable generic name HEIGHT_LENGTH user equally choose pass weight height files preferred. using following code: metadata now looks body length 65cm:
code: data(who_wt_for_lgth_boys) data(who_wt_for_lgth_girls)  who_wt_for_lgth <- who_wt_for_lgth_boys %>%   mutate(SEX = "M") %>%   bind_rows(who_wt_for_lgth_girls %>%     mutate(SEX = "F")) %>%   mutate(HEIGHT_LENGTHU = "cm") %>%   rename(HEIGHT_LENGTH = Length)

what: Derive Additional Variables for Anthropometric indicators
title: Creating a Pediatrics ADVS ADaM
text: order able compare reference files need know child’s age length/height respectively time vital signs assessment. need first derived variables ADVS. Remember ensure unit matches reference files metadata comparing , .e. “days” age “cm” length/height examples . Note standard reference files use different units intervals . example look “Age” charts provides day CDC gives every half month. converting days still leaves challenge join patient’s current age falls interval (e.g. 24.5 25 months CDC). package functions took simple approach use nearest age metadata, rather apply form interpolation. alternative method use derive current age according exact intervals metadata order exact join, examples just kept days.

previous_headings: Programming Workflow > Derive Additional Variables for Anthropometric indicators
what: Derived Variables for Parameters by Age
title: Creating a Pediatrics ADVS ADaM
text: variable current analysis age achieved using following code (might first need derive BRTHDT already available ADSL, including partial date imputation rules possible study data collection rules): age variables look:
code: # Calculate Current Analysis Age AAGECUR and unit AAGECURU advs <- advs %>%   derive_vars_duration(     new_var = AAGECUR,     new_var_unit = AAGECURU,     start_date = BRTHDT,     end_date = ADT   )

previous_headings: Programming Workflow > Derive Additional Variables for Anthropometric indicators
what: Derived Variables for Weight by Length/Height
title: Creating a Pediatrics ADVS ADaM
text: Similar , variable current analysis length/height achieved using following code:
code: # Derive Current HEIGHT/LENGTH at each time point Temporary variable advs <- advs %>%   derive_vars_merged(     dataset_add = advs,     by_vars = c(get_admiral_option("subject_keys"), exprs(AVISIT)),     filter_add = PARAMCD == "HEIGHT" & toupper(VSSTRESU) == "CM",     new_vars = exprs(HGTTMP = AVAL, HGTTMPU = VSSTRESU)   )

previous_headings: Programming Workflow
what: Derive Additional Parameters for Anthropometric indicators
title: Creating a Pediatrics ADVS ADaM
text: Now get important section show create new records derived pediatrics parameter. certain examples included , ’ll find parameters example template script referenced bottom vignette.

previous_headings: Programming Workflow > Derive Additional Parameters for Anthropometric indicators
title: Creating a Pediatrics ADVS ADaM
text: Parameters BMI Age z-score percentile achieved using derive_params_growth_age() function follows: rare case z-score percentile needed leave either respective set_values_to_ arguments. important remind importance metadata supplied function via meta_criteria argument. default case package taking standards children <2 years age CDC standards children >=2 years age. user free supply choice metadata reference files prefer. BMI parameters , ’ll notice code set bmi_cdc_correction = TRUE. opted use CDC developed extended percentiles (>95%) monitor high BMI values . left argument default FALSE value CDC metadata 2000 CDC Growth Chart BMI used. newly derived parameters look: height parameters age, noted growth chart use children <2 years age refers body length, whereas CDC growth chart children >=2 years age refers height. explained thoroughly next section.
code: ## Derive Anthropometric indicators (Z-Scores/Percentiles-for-Age) based on Standard Growth Charts ## For BMI by Age advs <- advs %>%   derive_params_growth_age(     by_vars = c(get_admiral_option("subject_keys"), exprs(AVISIT)),     sex = SEX,     age = AAGECUR,     age_unit = AAGECURU,     meta_criteria = bmi_for_age,     parameter = VSTESTCD == "BMI",     analysis_var = AVAL,     bmi_cdc_correction = TRUE,     set_values_to_sds = exprs(       PARAMCD = "BMISDS",       PARAM = "BMI-for-age z-score"     ),     set_values_to_pctl = exprs(       PARAMCD = "BMIPCTL",       PARAM = "BMI-for-age percentile"     )   )

previous_headings: Programming Workflow > Derive Additional Parameters for Anthropometric indicators
title: Creating a Pediatrics ADVS ADaM
text: Parameters Weight Length/Height z-score percentile children 2 years age achieved using following code, assumes “HEIGHT” parameter always collected body length (recumbent length). ’ll notice derive_params_growth_height() function used similar used , now passing height instead age. consulted acting pediatrician advised rarely investigators guided measure use. depends mainly age child able stand (2 years average) well preference measurer. strict CRF (case report form) guidelines standing height (rather body length) measured, add 0.7 cm values approximate child’s body length. alternatively provide different source reference files height allow parameter derivation children >2 years age, package recommendation.
code: advs <- advs %>%   restrict_derivation(     derivation = derive_params_growth_height,     args = params(       by_vars = c(get_admiral_option("subject_keys"), exprs(AVISIT)),       sex = SEX,       height = HGTTMP,       height_unit = HGTTMPU,       meta_criteria = who_wt_for_lgth,       parameter = VSTESTCD == "WEIGHT",       analysis_var = AVAL,       set_values_to_sds = exprs(         PARAMCD = "WGTHSDS",         PARAM = "Weight-for-length/height Z-Score"       ),       set_values_to_pctl = exprs(         PARAMCD = "WGTHPCTL",         PARAM = "Weight-for-length/height Percentile"       )     ),     filter = AAGECUR < 730.5   )

what: Derive interpolated rows for the CDC charts (>=2 yrs old) — derive_interp_records
title: Derive interpolated rows for the CDC charts (>=2 yrs old) — derive_interp_records
text: Derive interpolated rows CDC charts (>=2 yrs old) age days following parameters: HEIGHT, WEIGHT BMI

title: Derive interpolated rows for the CDC charts (>=2 yrs old) — derive_interp_records
Derive interpolated rows for the CDC charts (>=2 yrs old) — derive_interp_records
text: dataset Input metadataset variables AGE, AGEU, SEX, L, M, S expected dataset BMI additional variables P95 Sigma expected dataset Note AGE must days AGEU equal "DAYS" by_vars Grouping variables variable dataset identifies group observations interpolate separately. parameter CDC/metadata parameter Permitted Values: "WEIGHT", "HEIGHT" "BMI" - Must NULL e.g. parameter = "WEIGHT", parameter = "HEIGHT",   parameter = "BMI".

title: Derive interpolated rows for the CDC charts (>=2 yrs old) — derive_interp_records
text: input dataset plus additional interpolated records.

title: Derive interpolated rows for the CDC charts (>=2 yrs old) — derive_interp_records
code: library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) library(rlang, warn.conflicts = FALSE)  cdc_htage <- admiralpeds::cdc_htage %>%   mutate(     SEX = case_when(       SEX == 1 ~ "M",       SEX == 2 ~ "F",       TRUE ~ NA_character_     ),     # Ensure first that Age unit is "DAYS"     AGE = round(AGE * 30.4375)   ) %>%   # Interpolate the AGE by SEX   derive_interp_records(     by_vars = exprs(SEX),     parameter = "HEIGHT"   )  print(cdc_htage) #> # A tibble: 13,152 × 5 #>    SEX     AGE     L     M      S #>    <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> #>  1 F       730  1.07  85.0 0.0408 #>  2 F       731  1.07  85.0 0.0408 #>  3 F       732  1.07  85.0 0.0408 #>  4 F       733  1.07  85.1 0.0408 #>  5 F       734  1.07  85.1 0.0408 #>  6 F       735  1.07  85.1 0.0408 #>  7 F       736  1.06  85.1 0.0408 #>  8 F       737  1.06  85.2 0.0408 #>  9 F       738  1.06  85.2 0.0408 #> 10 F       739  1.06  85.2 0.0408 #> # ℹ 13,142 more rows

what: Derive Anthropometric indicators (Z-Scores/Percentiles-for-Age) based on Standard Growth Charts — derive_params_growth_age
title: Derive Anthropometric indicators (Z-Scores/Percentiles-for-Age) based on Standard Growth Charts — derive_params_growth_age
text: Derive Anthropometric indicators (Z-Scores/Percentiles--Age) based Standard Growth Charts Height/Weight/BMI/Head Circumference Age

title: Derive Anthropometric indicators (Z-Scores/Percentiles-for-Age) based on Standard Growth Charts — derive_params_growth_age
code: derive_params_growth_age(   dataset,   by_vars = NULL,   sex,   age,   age_unit,   meta_criteria,   parameter,   analysis_var,   bmi_cdc_correction = FALSE,   set_values_to_sds = NULL,   set_values_to_pctl = NULL )

title: Derive Anthropometric indicators (Z-Scores/Percentiles-for-Age) based on Standard Growth Charts — derive_params_growth_age
text: dataset Input dataset variables specified sex, age, age_unit, parameter, analysis_var expected dataset. by_vars Grouping variables variables dataset identifies unique subject visit expected. Permitted Values: list variables created exprs(), e.g exprs(USUBJID, VISIT). sex Sex character vector expected. Expected Values: M, F age Current Age numeric vector expected. Note actual age current visit. age_unit Age Unit character vector expected. Expected values: 'days' 'weeks' 'months' meta_criteria Metadata dataset metadata dataset following expected variables: AGE, AGEU, SEX, L, M, S dataset can derived CDC/user-defined datasets. CDC/growth chart metadata datasets available package require small modifications. age value dataset falls two AGE values meta_criteria, L/M/S values chosen/mapped AGE smaller absolute difference value age. e.g. dataset current age 27.49 months, metadata contains records 27 28 months, L/M/S corresponding 27 months record used. AGE - Age AGEU - Age Unit SEX - Sex L - Power Box-Cox transformation normality M - Median S - Coefficient variation parameter Anthropometric measurement parameter calculate z-score percentile condition expected input dataset VSTESTCD/PARAMCD want growth derivations: e.g. parameter = VSTESTCD == "WEIGHT". CDC/metadata available Height, Weight, BMI, Head Circumference available admiralpeds package. analysis_var Variable containing anthropometric measurement numeric vector expected, e.g. AVAL, VSSTRESN bmi_cdc_correction Extended CDC BMI--age correction logical scalar, e.g. TRUE/FALSE expected. CDC developed extended percentiles (>95%) monitor high BMI values, set TRUE CDC's correction applied. set_values_to_sds Variables set Z-Scores specified variables set specified values new observations. example, set_values_to_sds(exprs(PARAMCD = “BMIASDS”, PARAM = “BMI--age z-score”)) defines parameter code parameter. formula calculate Z-score follows: $$\frac{((\frac{obs}{M})^L - 1)}{L * S}$$ "obs" observed value respective anthropometric measure calculated. Permitted Values: List variable-value pairs left default value, NULL, parameter derived output dataset set_values_to_pctl Variables set Percentile specified variables set specified values new observations. example, set_values_to_pctl(exprs(PARAMCD = “BMIAPCTL”, PARAM = “BMI--age percentile”)) defines parameter code parameter. Permitted Values: List variable-value pair left default value, NULL, parameter derived output dataset

title: Derive Anthropometric indicators (Z-Scores/Percentiles-for-Age) based on Standard Growth Charts — derive_params_growth_age
text: input dataset additional records new parameter added.

title: Derive Anthropometric indicators (Z-Scores/Percentiles-for-Age) based on Standard Growth Charts — derive_params_growth_age
code: library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) library(lubridate, warn.conflicts = FALSE) library(rlang, warn.conflicts = FALSE) library(admiral, warn.conflicts = FALSE)  advs <- dm_peds %>%   select(USUBJID, BRTHDTC, SEX) %>%   right_join(., vs_peds, by = "USUBJID") %>%   mutate(     VSDT = ymd(VSDTC),     BRTHDT = ymd(BRTHDTC)   ) %>%   derive_vars_duration(     new_var = AGECUR_D,     new_var_unit = CURU_D,     start_date = BRTHDT,     end_date = VSDT,     out_unit = "days",     trunc_out = FALSE   ) %>%   derive_vars_duration(     new_var = AGECUR_M,     new_var_unit = CURU_M,     start_date = BRTHDT,     end_date = VSDT,     out_unit = "months",     trunc_out = FALSE   ) %>%   mutate(     AGECUR = ifelse(AGECUR_D >= 365.25 * 2, AGECUR_M, AGECUR_D),     AGECURU = ifelse(AGECUR_D >= 365.25 * 2, CURU_M, CURU_D)   )  # metadata is in months cdc_meta_criteria <- admiralpeds::cdc_wtage %>%   mutate(     age_unit = "months",     SEX = ifelse(SEX == 1, "M", "F")   )  # metadata is in days who_meta_criteria <- bind_rows(   (admiralpeds::who_wt_for_age_boys %>%     mutate(       SEX = "M",       age_unit = "days"     )   ),   (admiralpeds::who_wt_for_age_girls %>%     mutate(       SEX = "F",       age_unit = "days"     )   ) ) %>%   rename(AGE = Day)  criteria <- bind_rows(   cdc_meta_criteria,   who_meta_criteria ) %>%   rename(AGEU = age_unit)  derive_params_growth_age(   advs,   by_vars = exprs(STUDYID, USUBJID, VISIT),   sex = SEX,   age = AGECUR,   age_unit = AGECURU,   meta_criteria = criteria,   parameter = VSTESTCD == "WEIGHT",   analysis_var = VSSTRESN,   set_values_to_sds = exprs(     PARAMCD = "WGASDS",     PARAM = "Weight-for-age z-score"   ),   set_values_to_pctl = exprs(     PARAMCD = "WGAPCTL",     PARAM = "Weight-for-age percentile"   ) ) #> # A tibble: 246 × 39 #>    USUBJID     BRTHDTC  SEX   STUDYID DOMAIN VSSEQ VSTESTCD VSTEST VSPOS VSORRES #>    <chr>       <chr>    <chr> <chr>   <chr>  <int> <chr>    <chr>  <chr> <chr>   #>  1 01-701-1015 2013-01… F     CDISCP… VS         1 BMI      BMI    NA    16.577… #>  2 01-701-1015 2013-01… F     CDISCP… VS         5 BMI      BMI    NA    16.615… #>  3 01-701-1015 2013-01… F     CDISCP… VS         9 BMI      BMI    NA    16.697… #>  4 01-701-1015 2013-01… F     CDISCP… VS        13 BMI      BMI    NA    16.816… #>  5 01-701-1015 2013-01… F     CDISCP… VS        17 BMI      BMI    NA    16.824… #>  6 01-701-1015 2013-01… F     CDISCP… VS        21 BMI      BMI    NA    16.915… #>  7 01-701-1015 2013-01… F     CDISCP… VS        25 BMI      BMI    NA    17.051… #>  8 01-701-1015 2013-01… F     CDISCP… VS        29 BMI      BMI    NA    17.162… #>  9 01-701-1015 2013-01… F     CDISCP… VS        33 BMI      BMI    NA    17.248… #> 10 01-701-1015 2013-01… F     CDISCP… VS        37 BMI      BMI    NA    17.433… #> # ℹ 236 more rows #> # ℹ 29 more variables: VSORRESU <chr>, VSSTRESC <chr>, VSSTRESN <dbl>, #> #   VSSTRESU <chr>, VSSTAT <chr>, VSLOC <chr>, VSBLFL <chr>, VISITNUM <dbl>, #> #   VISIT <chr>, VISITDY <int>, VSDTC <chr>, VSDY <int>, VSTPT <chr>, #> #   VSTPTNUM <dbl>, VSELTM <chr>, VSTPTREF <chr>, VSEVAL <chr>, EPOCH <chr>, #> #   VSDT <date>, BRTHDT <date>, AGECUR_D <dbl>, CURU_D <chr>, AGECUR_M <dbl>, #> #   CURU_M <chr>, AGECUR <dbl>, AGECURU <chr>, AVAL <dbl>, PARAMCD <chr>, …

title: Derive Anthropometric indicators (Z-Scores/Percentiles-for-Height/Length) based on Standard Growth Charts — derive_params_growth_height
code: derive_params_growth_height(   dataset,   by_vars = NULL,   sex,   height,   height_unit,   meta_criteria,   parameter,   analysis_var,   set_values_to_sds = NULL,   set_values_to_pctl = NULL )

title: Derive Anthropometric indicators (Z-Scores/Percentiles-for-Height/Length) based on Standard Growth Charts — derive_params_growth_height
text: dataset Input dataset variables specified sex, height, height_unit, parameter, analysis_var expected dataset. by_vars Grouping variables variables dataset identifies unique subject visit expected. Permitted Values: list variables created exprs(), e.g exprs(USUBJID, VISIT). sex Sex character vector expected. Expected Values: M, F height Current Height/length numeric vector expected. Note actual height/length current visit. height_unit Height/Length Unit character vector expected. Expected values: 'cm' meta_criteria Metadata dataset metadata dataset following expected variables: HEIGHT_LENGTH, HEIGHT_LENGTHU, SEX, L, M, S dataset can derived user-defined datasets. growth chart metadata datasets available package require small modifications. Datasets who_wt_for_lgth_boys/who_wt_for_lgth_girls applicable subject age < 730.5 days. height value dataset falls two HEIGHT_LENGTH values meta_criteria, L/M/S values chosen/mapped HEIGHT_LENGTH smaller absolute difference value height. e.g. dataset current age 50.49 cm, metadata contains records 50 51 cm, L/M/S corresponding 50 cm record used. HEIGHT_LENGTH - Height/Length HEIGHT_LENGTHU - Height/Length Unit SEX - Sex L - Power Box-Cox transformation normality M - Median S - Coefficient variation parameter Anthropometric measurement parameter calculate z-score percentile condition expected input dataset VSTESTCD/PARAMCD want growth derivations: e.g. parameter = VSTESTCD == "WEIGHT". metadata available Weight available admiralpeds package. Weight measures expected unit "kg". analysis_var Variable containing anthropometric measurement numeric vector expected, e.g. AVAL, VSSTRESN set_values_to_sds Variables set Z-Scores specified variables set specified values new observations. example, set_values_to_sds(exprs(PARAMCD = "WGTHSDS", PARAM = "Weight--height z-score")) defines parameter code parameter. formula calculate Z-score follows: $$\frac{((\frac{obs}{M})^L - 1)}{L * S}$$ "obs" observed value respective anthropometric measure calculated. Permitted Values: List variable-value pairs left default value, NULL, parameter derived output dataset set_values_to_pctl Variables set Percentile specified variables set specified values new observations. example, set_values_to_pctl(exprs(PARAMCD = "WGTHPCTL", PARAM = "Weight--height percentile")) defines parameter code parameter. Permitted Values: List variable-value pair left default value, NULL, parameter derived output dataset

title: Derive Anthropometric indicators (Z-Scores/Percentiles-for-Height/Length) based on Standard Growth Charts — derive_params_growth_height
text: input dataset additional records new parameter added.

title: Derive Anthropometric indicators (Z-Scores/Percentiles-for-Height/Length) based on Standard Growth Charts — derive_params_growth_height
code: library(dplyr, warn.conflicts = FALSE) library(lubridate, warn.conflicts = FALSE) library(rlang, warn.conflicts = FALSE) library(admiral, warn.conflicts = FALSE)  # derive weight for height/length only for those under 2 years old using WHO # weight for length reference file advs <- dm_peds %>%   select(USUBJID, BRTHDTC, SEX) %>%   right_join(., vs_peds, by = "USUBJID") %>%   mutate(     VSDT = ymd(VSDTC),     BRTHDT = ymd(BRTHDTC)   ) %>%   derive_vars_duration(     new_var = AAGECUR,     new_var_unit = AAGECURU,     start_date = BRTHDT,     end_date = VSDT,     out_unit = "days"   )  heights <- vs_peds %>%   filter(VSTESTCD == "HEIGHT") %>%   select(USUBJID, VSSTRESN, VSSTRESU, VSDTC) %>%   rename(     HGTTMP = VSSTRESN,     HGTTMPU = VSSTRESU   )  advs <- advs %>%   right_join(., heights, by = c("USUBJID", "VSDTC"))  advs_under2 <- advs %>%   filter(AAGECUR < 730.5)  who_under2 <- bind_rows(   (admiralpeds::who_wt_for_lgth_boys %>%     mutate(       SEX = "M",       height_unit = "cm"     )   ),   (admiralpeds::who_wt_for_lgth_girls %>%     mutate(       SEX = "F",       height_unit = "cm"     )   ) ) %>%   rename(     HEIGHT_LENGTH = Length,     HEIGHT_LENGTHU = height_unit   )  derive_params_growth_height(   advs_under2,   by_vars = exprs(STUDYID, USUBJID, VISIT),   sex = SEX,   height = HGTTMP,   height_unit = HGTTMPU,   meta_criteria = who_under2,   parameter = VSTESTCD == "WEIGHT",   analysis_var = VSSTRESN,   set_values_to_sds = exprs(     PARAMCD = "WGTHSDS",     PARAM = "Weight-for-height/length z-score"   ),   set_values_to_pctl = exprs(     PARAMCD = "WGTHPCTL",     PARAM = "Weight-for-height/length percentile"   ) ) #> # A tibble: 162 × 37 #>    USUBJID     BRTHDTC  SEX   STUDYID DOMAIN VSSEQ VSTESTCD VSTEST VSPOS VSORRES #>    <chr>       <chr>    <chr> <chr>   <chr>  <int> <chr>    <chr>  <chr> <chr>   #>  1 01-701-1015 2013-01… F     CDISCP… VS         1 BMI      BMI    NA    16.577… #>  2 01-701-1015 2013-01… F     CDISCP… VS         5 BMI      BMI    NA    16.615… #>  3 01-701-1015 2013-01… F     CDISCP… VS         9 BMI      BMI    NA    16.697… #>  4 01-701-1015 2013-01… F     CDISCP… VS        13 BMI      BMI    NA    16.816… #>  5 01-701-1015 2013-01… F     CDISCP… VS        17 BMI      BMI    NA    16.824… #>  6 01-701-1015 2013-01… F     CDISCP… VS        21 BMI      BMI    NA    16.915… #>  7 01-701-1015 2013-01… F     CDISCP… VS        25 BMI      BMI    NA    17.051… #>  8 01-701-1015 2013-01… F     CDISCP… VS        29 BMI      BMI    NA    17.162… #>  9 01-701-1015 2013-01… F     CDISCP… VS        33 BMI      BMI    NA    17.248… #> 10 01-701-1015 2013-01… F     CDISCP… VS        37 BMI      BMI    NA    17.433… #> # ℹ 152 more rows #> # ℹ 27 more variables: VSORRESU <chr>, VSSTRESC <chr>, VSSTRESN <dbl>, #> #   VSSTRESU <chr>, VSSTAT <chr>, VSLOC <chr>, VSBLFL <chr>, VISITNUM <dbl>, #> #   VISIT <chr>, VISITDY <int>, VSDTC <chr>, VSDY <int>, VSTPT <chr>, #> #   VSTPTNUM <dbl>, VSELTM <chr>, VSTPTREF <chr>, VSEVAL <chr>, EPOCH <chr>, #> #   VSDT <date>, BRTHDT <date>, AAGECUR <dbl>, AAGECURU <chr>, HGTTMP <dbl>, #> #   HGTTMPU <chr>, AVAL <dbl>, PARAMCD <chr>, PARAM <chr>
